text: Then, he said, "like a fish out of water," and all he could do was to overhear them at their councils, and that my dancing days are over.

passages.full_quote: <used>Then, he said, h</used>e would endeavour to see her in the course of this day.
Both felt rather anxious to hear him speak again; and after a few minutes silence, <used>he said, "A</used>nother thing must be taken into consideration too -- Mrs. Elton does not talk"

passages.fragment: he said , `` like a fish out of water , '' and all he could do was to
passages.full_quote: Mr. Dance stood there, as <used>he said, "like a fish out of water," and all he could do was to</used> dispatch a man to B -- -- to warn the cutter

passages.fragment: could do was to overhear them at their councils , and that my
passages.full_quote: I began to feel that I was neglecting my business, that since I had been so foolhardy as to come ashore with these desperadoes, the least I <used>could do was to overhear them at their councils, and that my</used> plain and obvious duty was to draw as close as I could manage, under the favourable ambush of the crouching trees

passages.fragment: , and that my dancing days are over
passages.full_quote: said he, "I shall have great pleasure, I am sure -- for, though beginning to feel myself rather an old married man<used>, and that my dancing days are over</used>, it would give me very great pleasure at any time to stand up with an old friend like Mrs"
Any thing else I should be most happy to do, at your command -- but <used>my dancing days are over</used>.
